tagger.tagNote: First pass; Colleen Doody, second pass 3/10/98

div.head: Speech of Hon. John L. Dawson of Pennsylvania on the State of the Union
div.summary: Prints concluding half of the speech given by John L. Dawson before the state legislature on February 24. In it, Dawson assails the Lincoln administration for executing the war in a way that will destroy the Union.

div.head: The Spotted Fever
div.summary: Warns readers about the symptoms of spotted fever, which recently has taken the lives of thousands in Philadelphia.

div.head: The Johnstown Homicide
div.summary: Reports that Joseph Moore was convicted of murder in the second degree for the death of Mr. Marbourg. Moore was sentenced to six years in the penitentiary.

page.pageNote: Poetry and fiction, columns 1-4, reports of troop movement in Dalton, Georgia, column 5, classified ads, columns 5-6

div.head: The Position of the Democracy
div.excerpt: "The policy on which the war is, at present, conducted, is destructive of the end to be attained. The war was commenced to put down military usurpation. It was not intended to be a war against communities, individuals, or their property and rights, but a war in defense of the Constitution, the laws and for the preservation of the Union. This is still its true and proper object, and to this we must return if we would have an early and stable peace."
div.summary: Argues that the Democratic party is loyal to the Union, perhaps more so than the Republican party.

div.head: Unconditional Unionism
div.excerpt: "They are not for the Union at all, unless it is a Union to suit their party views."
div.summary: Suggests that those men who support an "unconditional union," in which the federal government could wield substantially more power, are actually disunionists.

div.head: Call Upon the Leaguers
div.excerpt: "They are willing to shed ink in writing resolutions favoring a prosecution of the war, but they have no idea of shedding their blood."
div.summary: Scoffs at attempts by an abolitionist newspaper to encourage members of abolition leagues and clubs to fight for the Union.

div.head: A Soldier
div.summary: Suggests that whiskey can explain why a soldier recently was spotted burning copies of a Democratic newspaper.

div.head: Democratic State Conventions
div.summary: Summarizes proceedings of the Democratic State Convention held on March 24 in Philadelphia. Reports that the Convention voted to support General George B. McClellan for President.

div.head: Fremont in the Field
div.summary: Suggests that the expected candidacy of General Fremont as a Republican candidate for President could derail the hopes of both Chase and Lincoln.

div.head: The State Quotas Under the Last Call for Volunteers
div.summary: Lists the most recent quotas established by Lincoln for the number of men needed to volunteer from each state. Pennsylvania's quota is 26,302.

div.head: Congressional
div.summary: Reports on the recent proceedings of the Confederate Congress, including the consideration of a bill to promote enlistments.

page.pageNote: Report on the extent of Union loyalty in Louisiana, column 3

div.head: Street Lamps and Gas Light
div.summary: Asks that the person in charge of the gas lamps in the town's streets exercise common sense when deciding when to light the lamps. The editor says that the lights are often lit when the moon can provide plenty of light.

div.head: Spring Election
Tribute of Respect
div.trailer: B. La Trobe Maurer, Pres., Jacob Jarrett, Secretary
div.summary: Publishes tribute to Jacob Lutz passed on March 20 by the Friendship Fire company. Lutz was a member of the company who died from wounds received in the battle of Chickamauga.

div.head: Dr. S. G. Lane
div.summary: Reports that Dr. S. G. Lane has been appointed the Surgeon of the Board of Enrollment of this district.

div.head: Ryster's Store
div.summary: Expresses approval at the improvements made by Messrs. Ryster and Brother in their store.

div.head: Clergyman on Trial
div.summary: Questions the punishment issued to Rev. Kepler by the Methodist Conference at Altoona for preaching the divinity of slavery. The editor suggests that, had he preached the divinity of miscegenation, he would have been embraced by the Conference.

Announces the formation of a company for the First Battalion of three-years volunteers. The recruiting station is at the office of Esquire Hamman, and will proceed under the direction of Capt. John Doebler, Lieutenant John A. Seiders, and Lieutenant Benjamin F. Zook.

div.head: Dangerous Counterfeit
div.summary: Warns readers that counterfeit twenty-dollar notes are now circulating.

div.head: Fire at Mont Alto
div.summary: Reports that a fire on March 4 destroyed the main part of the dwelling of Mrs. N. B. Hughes. States that her Mont Alto neighbors' exertions saved the right wing of the building.

div.head: Killed in an Ore Bank
div.summary: Reports that Jacob Helman was killed on March 9 when the earth caved in at Bombarger's ore bank.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 17, Rev. William A. West married Robert Kerr and Martha Elizabeth Campbell, daughter of Andrew Campbell.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 24, Rev. William McElroy married Captain Arthur Bennet, Company I, 21st Pennsylvania Cavalry, and Kate Virdier.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. A. M. Whetstone married George W. Kleise, of Lancaster City and the1st Pennsylvania Cavalry, and Elizabeth Kaudle on March 20.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 23, Rev. A. M. Whetstone married Abraham S. Butler and Emma Ferry.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 22, Rev. S. McHenry married Samuel Hoover and Lizzie Rife.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. S. McHenry married Abraham S. Oyer and Maggie H. Timmons on March 24 at the residence of Jacob Eberly, Esq.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 24, Rev. Thomas Barnhart married Louis M. Rinehart and Hannah Ensminger.

div.head: Married
div.summary: Rev. E. Breidenbaugh married Henry Brubaker and Elizabeth Rinniker on March 9.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 24, Rev. E. Breidenbaugh married George W. Shrader and Melinda Miller.

div.head: Married
div.summary: On March 24, Rev. Thomas McCauley of Philadelphia, assisted by Rev. J. W. Wightman, married Dr. W. Howard King, Surgeon of the 21st Pennsylvania Volunteer Cavalry, and Maggie M. McCauley, daughter of Mrs. M. M. McCauley.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 10, Tirsan Blythe Kirkpatrick, 3 years, and James McClellan Kirkpatrick, 1 year, died. Both were the children of James Kirkpatrick.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Ann Elisabeth Crouse, daughter of Benjamin and Rebecca Crouse, died on March 17 at age 14.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Jacob Lute died in Military Hospital at Chattanooga on March 6. He was 21 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Sarah Rebecca Shirk, daughter of Jacob G. and Rebecca M. Shirk, died on March 19. She was 1 month old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Elizabeth Werdebaugh, 3-year-old daughter of Truman and Elizabeth Werdebaugh, died on March 24 of diphtheria.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Thomas James Boyd, son of Captain Robert Boyd, died on March 17 at age 7 months.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Mrs. Jane Bradley, wife of John Bradley, dec'd, died on March 14 at age 61.

div.head: Died
div.summary: William D. Riddle, son of George Riddle, died on March 17 at age 2.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 18, Elizabeth Cosey, wife of Jacob Cosey, died in Antrim Township at age 20.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 21, Sarah M. Davison, wife of William H. Davison, died at age 28.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Thomas Creigh, son of John D. Creigh, died on March 14 in San Francisco. He was 31 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: George Etter, Sr. died on March 12 at age 64.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Edward Monn Grove, son of John and Margaret Grove, died on March 22 at age 2.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Emma B. Leedy died on March 25 in St. Thomas. She was 6 years old.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Elias Brunner died on March 25 at age 73.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Solomon Knepper died on March 22 at age 33.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Otilla Bickley, daughter of George Bickley, died on March 24 at age 6.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Charles Henry Shanabrook, son of Mary Ann and Charles Shanabrook, died on March 27 at age 2 years.

div.head: Died
div.summary: On March 21, the infant child of William Osbraugh died at age 3 weeks.

div.head: Died
div.summary: Rachael Byers died on March 25 at the residence of Rev. John Plum. She was 84 years old.

div.head: Latest News by the Mails!
div.summary: Reports that the citizens of Kentucky are growing anxious about rumors of a rebel invasion.

page.pageNote: Reports of troop movement in Louisiana, column 2; classified ads, columns 3-6
